Russia suffered endlessly under communism and "egalitarianism". Being a 
Christian in Soviet Russia and openly proclaiming your faith could land you 
in jail, a work camp or even dead. I suspect that now that communism has 
fallen, and socialism has been confined to the dustbin of Russia's history, 
many in Russia see Christian values as a way to transform their society and 
move far away from the Left-wing politics of Russia's past. Proclaiming 
Russia as a Christian country is a way for many of Russia's new generation 
to rebel against the old regime and go back to their roots, one might say.

Given that saying that homosexuality is a sin and that it should not be 
encouraged or advertised so openly like it is in the West, would fit that 
narrative of unearthing traditions that were lost until very recently. 
However, actually trying to kill or harm people simply because you don't 
agree with their lifestyle, is 1) very un-Christiand, and 2) is just how 
the Soviet Union used to treat decenters , notably many Christians. How 
ironic.﻿

☺ Everybody in Western Europe and the US seems to have misunderstood what 
that notorious law was all about in fact. Let me get this straight for you 
then. Nobody's punishing gay people in Russia, nor are they persecuted for 
being who they are either. Gay people used to get persecuted/imprisoned in 
the USSR but not now. After more than 20 years since it's collapsed for 
god's sakes. You mess things up cuz your anti-Russian media keeps telling 
you so. Yes, there's some bickering, sometimes violence, common distaste 
and even hatred towards openly gay people yet it depends on the particular 
situation/background. People/families/specific environment are all 
different either. It's hard to come clean in Russia and feel absolutely 
free and accepted in terms of social attitude but you can keep it a secret 
and live a normal life. Just stay discreet and you will be fine. Come out 
if you want to and don't give a damn about what other people say. It's up 
to anyone. Even though you have to lie to people to stay within your 
comfort zone or if you're desperate and brave enough fight for what really 
matters to you, winning eventually or ending up disgraced and rejected. 
Yes, Russian people are very conservative and firm in their "old-fashioned" 
beliefs and their keeping traditional values kinda thing, but nobody puts 
gays behind bars in Russia. The law is to ban the LGBT-propaganda in 
Russia. Which means you will never see a gay pride parade marching through 
Moscow or something. There're legal gay clubs in the biggest Russian 
metropolises (St. Petersburg, Moscow and others) though, which was beyond 
unimaginable at the times of the Soviet Union era. However, you will never 
see this kinda stuff on TV, ads, shows, public events, speeches etc. On the 
other side gay people could be found among lots of Russian celebrities, in 
the Russian show-business and popping up on TV now and then, just like 
separate individuals, professionals at what they do for instance. Like 
everybody knows that, that effeminate makeup artist is gay in some makeover 
program like from ugly to pretty kinda show and nobody gives a shit. 
America's next top-model's been broadcasted in Russia for more than 6 years 
by now and there're lots of queer people there as well. Nobody's gonna 
shoot you down or execute you if you get busted, like in the Middle East. 
There're gay websites, gay chats, gay social networks activity in the 
Russian segment of the Internet where they can communicate freely or seek a 
soulmate/one night stand without any bugging and further prosecution. 
Russians are indeed intolerant to gays mostly but not ferocious. Then again 
it depends. The other day I saw a gay couple in the restaraunt holding 
hands, taking care of each other, sweet talking so it didn't look that 
gross but pretty obvious at the same time, and nobody cared again. So just 
try to get more proper information and don't blow things out of proportion. 
P.S. Coming from a Russian person who's fairly neutral to gays and 
convinced it's only their business but still against gay propaganda, gay 
parades, gay marriages and gay adoption. Cheers! ☺﻿
